study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of Lactobacillus casei on various stages of biofilm formation in Gardnerella species and its potential role in treating bacterial vaginosis.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei Xbb-LC-1 inhibited Gardnerella species biofilm formation, particularly when added at the initial stage. Maintaining an acidic vaginal environment (pH <4.5) with Lactobacillus dominance significantly prevented biofilm formation.
population_specificity: Gardnerella species, including Gardnerella vaginalis ATCC 14018 and six clinically isolated strains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of heat-killed Lactobacillus casei DKGF7 in improving irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) symptoms in a rat model and to explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significantly better stool consistency, lower serum corticosterone levels, reduced colonic inflammatory cytokines, and higher expression of tight junction proteins compared to the control group. These findings suggest heat-killed L. casei DKGF7 may be a potential therapeutic strategy for IBS.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced IBS via restraint stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the tumor-inhibiting effects of combining Lactobacillus casei TD2a with GM-CSF on HPV-associated tumors in mice.
results_summary: The combination of L. casei and GM-CSF significantly enhanced tumor inhibition, immune responses (cytolytic and splenocyte proliferation), and cytokine levels (IFN-γ, IL-4, IL-12) while reducing IL-10 accumulation in the tumor microenvironment. The combined treatment also increased intratumoral TRAIL and suppressed tumor growth more effectively than individual treatments.
population_specificity: Transplanted mice with TC-1 tumors (HPV-associated tumor model).

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy of Lactobacillus paracasei CNCM I-1572 in preventing symptomatic recurrences and improving quality of life in patients with chronic bacterial prostatitis.
results_summary: The study found that 72.6% of patients reported clinical improvement, with significant reductions in symptom scores and antibiotic use, and no clinically relevant adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic bacterial prostatitis attending a single urological institution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant and immunomodulatory activities of exopolysaccharides (EPS) from Lactobacillus casei NA-2 in vitro.
results_summary: EPS demonstrated antioxidant activity by scavenging radicals and showed immunomodulatory effects by promoting ROS and TNF-α production in unstimulated macrophages while reducing NO and iNOS levels in LPS-induced macrophages. The study suggests EPS has potential anti-inflammatory and protective effects against oxidative damage.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 macrophages (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus casei improves fermentation quality and microbial community dynamics in alfalfa silage compared to untreated or cellulase-treated silage.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei significantly improved silage quality by lowering pH, increasing lactic acid content, and promoting Lactobacillus dominance in bacterial communities. The treatment also preserved leaf epicuticular wax structure better than untreated silage.
population_specificity: Alfalfa silage (first cutting, 29% dry matter).
study_duration: 56 days of ensiling followed by 3 days of air exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of Lactobacillus casei against carbon tetrachloride (CCl4)-induced reproductive injury and sperm toxicity in rats.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei improved reproductive hormone levels, antioxidant capacity, and spermatogenesis rates while down-regulating pro-apoptotic genes (Bax) and up-regulating anti-apoptotic genes (Bcl-2). It also enhanced testicular histomorphometric indices and sperm parameters.
population_specificity: Wistar rats (32 animals divided into four groups).
effective_dosage: Not specified (probiotic administered alongside 2 ml/kg CCl4).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which fermented milk containing Lactobacillus casei Zhang and Bifidobacterium animalis ssp. lactis V9 alleviates constipation symptoms.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in constipation symptoms, increased anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10, decreased proinflammatory markers, and altered metabolic pathways related to fatty acid and bile acid biosynthesis. The increase in B. animalis correlated with higher defecation frequency, and acylcarnitine positively influenced defecation.
population_specificity: Volunteers with chronic constipation symptoms

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Lactobacillus casei ZX633 on gut microbiota composition in infants with diarrhea, comparing it to healthy infants.
results_summary: L. casei ZX633 increased certain beneficial bacteria (E. coli, yeasts, LAB) and propionic acid while reducing other SCFAs, shifting microbial structure toward that of healthy infants. However, microbial diversity and richness decreased in the treatment group.
population_specificity: Infants with diarrhea (treatment group) and healthy infants (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prophylactic effects of five Lactobacillus casei strains on house dust mite (HDM)-induced asthma in mice.
results_summary: All five L. casei strains reduced granulocytes and Th2/Th17 inflammatory cytokines, with L. casei3 showing the most significant reduction in airway inflammation. Some strains also modulated immunoglobulin levels and gut microbiota composition, with L. casei3 exhibiting the highest prophylactic effect.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether milk fermented by Lactobacillus casei CRL431 (PFM) could reduce the side effects of capecitabine while maintaining its anti-tumor and anti-metastatic effects in breast cancer models.
results_summary: PFM reduced capecitabine side effects, improved immune response, and maintained anti-cancer/anti-metastasis effects in mouse models. It also independently reduced metastasis without side effects.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice (healthy, bearing breast cancer, or with potential metastasis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus casei strain T2 could alleviate demyelination symptoms and modulate inflammatory markers in a cuprizone-induced mouse model of multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus casei significantly reduced miR-155 expression and IL-17 levels in treated mice, suggesting it may reduce proinflammatory cytokines and demyelinating symptoms. The effects were observed across multiple treatment regimens, including combinations with vitamin D3.
population_specificity: Female C57BL/6 mice (8-10 weeks old)
study_duration: 4 weeks (for probiotic administration in each treatment group)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review randomized clinical studies investigating the effect of probiotics, including Lactobacillus Casei, on managing osteoarthritis-related pain and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in OA-related symptoms, including pain and impediment, but not stiffness, across the analyzed outcomes. Serum hs-CRP levels also showed improvement.
population_specificity: 501 participants with osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential role of gut microbiota in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and explore the feasibility of using Lactobacillus casei as a supplementary treatment for RA.
results_summary: The study suggests that Lactobacillus casei, a probiotic with immunomodulatory properties, has beneficial effects for RA in both murine and human models, contrasting with higher quantities of other bacteria found in RA patients.
population_specificity: Murine and human models (specific details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a DFM product containing Lactobacillus Casei and Lactobacillus acidophilus could reduce fecal shedding of E. coli O157:H7 in feedlot cattle.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in E. coli O157:H7 fecal prevalence or supershedding prevalence in cattle treated with the DFM product compared to controls. The results were consistent across both feedlots, with only one instance of a marginally significant effect (p=0.04) for supershedding in Nebraska.
population_specificity: Finishing commercial feedlot cattle in Kansas and Nebraska.
effective_dosage: 1 × 10^9 CFU per animal daily (combination of Lactobacillus acidophilus and Lactobacillus casei).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic potential of Lactobacillus casei Shirota in managing symptoms of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) through gut microbiota modulation.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus casei Shirota, among other probiotics, imparted positive effects in managing OCD symptoms by influencing the microbiota-gut-brain axis, neurotransmitter activity, and inflammatory pathways.
population_specificity: Individuals with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of Lactobacillus casei Zhang, in combination with other probiotics and atorvastatin, in treating hyperlipidemia by optimizing gut microbiota and reducing harmful bacteria.
results_summary: Probiotics, including Lactobacillus casei, improved gut microbial abundance and diversity, increased beneficial bacteria (e.g., Bifidobacterium, Lactobacillus), and reduced harmful bacteria (e.g., Escherichia). They also contributed to significant reductions in total cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL-C levels.
population_specificity: 33 patients with hyperlipidemia (18 in probiotic group, 15 in control group).
effective_dosage: 2 g once daily (probiotic blend) + atorvastatin 20 mg once daily.
interactions: Combined with atorvastatin (no adverse interactions mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of 3-month supplementation with oral probiotics (including Lactobacillus Casei) on quality of life and inflammatory markers in women with primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: The probiotic group showed improved mental health scores and potentially reduced nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug use, but there was no significant difference in quality of life scores or inflammatory markers compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Women with primary dysmenorrhea (72 patients, 36 in each arm).
effective_dosage: 5 billion colony-forming units per sachet (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of biotics, including Lactobacillus casei, in reducing the occurrence and severity of oral mucositis in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus casei, along with other probiotics, reduced the occurrence of oral mucositis in clinical studies and decreased its severity in pre-clinical studies. However, the evidence was marked by significant heterogeneity across studies.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing cancer treatment (specific cancer types not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the microbial contamination of removable orthodontic appliances and the efficacy of chlorhexidine gluconate spray in reducing cariogenic microorganisms, including Lactobacillus casei.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei was found in lower abundance compared to other cariogenic microorganisms like Streptococcus mutans and Streptococcus sobrinus. The use of chlorhexidine spray significantly reduced the number of Lactobacillus casei (P <0.05).
population_specificity: Children aged 7-11 years wearing removable orthodontic appliances.
effective_dosage: 0.12% chlorhexidine gluconate spray applied twice a week (days 4 and 7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Lactobacillus Casei Shirota on stool frequency, consistency, and integrative symptom scores in adults with chronic constipation.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus Casei Shirota did not significantly increase stool frequency or impact stool consistency compared to control, though probiotics overall showed some benefits for integrative symptom scores.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic constipation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of manual and interactive power toothbrushes on salivary levels of Lactobacillus casei in orthodontic patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in salivary L. casei levels between the manual and interactive power toothbrush groups at any time point (T0, T1, T2). The results suggest that brush type did not influence L. casei concentrations.
population_specificity: 40 orthodontic patients (20 females, 20 males; aged 12-18 years) with fixed orthodontic appliances.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on toothbrush type, not L. casei dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of two probiotic formulations, including Lactobacillus casei, in improving symptoms of functional constipation in adults.
results_summary: The study found that both probiotic formulations, including Lactobacillus casei, improved stool frequency and quality in adults with functional constipation, with no significant differences between groups. Only one mild adverse event (abdominal pain) was reported.
population_specificity: Adults with functional constipation.
effective_dosage: 8 billion CFU (including Lactobacillus casei) administered once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of a probiotic mixture containing Lactobacillus Casei in improving atopic dermatitis symptoms and reducing corticosteroid use in pediatric patients.
results_summary: The probiotic mixture significantly improved SCORAD and IGA scores compared to placebo and reduced corticosteroid use between weeks 6-12, though no significant difference was observed in total corticosteroid dose over the entire study period. Adverse events were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 4-17 years with atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: 1 × 10^9 colony-forming units per capsule daily (combined with Bifidobacterium lactis and Bifidobacterium longum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective function of surface layer protein (SLP) from Lactobacillus casei fb05 against the harmful effects of E. coli and Salmonella on intestinal tissue.
results_summary: The study found that L. casei fb05 SLP reduced pathogen adhesion to collagen and HT-29 cells by 45%-49% and inhibited pathogen-induced apoptosis by decreasing caspase-9 and caspase-3 activation.
population_specificity: In vitro study using HT-29 cells (human intestinal epithelial cell line) and collagen.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of synbiotic supplementation (including Lactobacillus casei) in reducing gut-derived uremic toxins and inflammation in chronic kidney disease patients.
results_summary: Synbiotic treatment enriched beneficial gut bacteria (including Lactobacillus), significantly reduced serum indoxyl sulfate, improved kidney function (eGFR), and decreased inflammation (hs-CRP), with only minor adverse effects (increased flatulence in two patients).
population_specificity: 34 nondialyzed chronic kidney disease patients (aged ≥18, eGFR 15–45 mL/minute).
effective_dosage: 32 billion CFU/day (combined with Lactobacillus acidophilus, Bifidobacterium lactis, and 3.2 g inulin).

study_goal: The abstract does not specify the researchers' goals regarding Lactobacillus Casei.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to Lactobacillus Casei.
population_specificity: Not specified in the provided abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether Lactobacillus casei, when added to standard Helicobacter pylori eradication therapy in children, improves eradication rates and reduces adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found low-quality evidence that Lactobacillus casei increases the eradication rate of H. pylori and decreases adverse effects, though the evidence is limited due to study heterogeneity and only one randomized controlled trial. Synbiotics showed only a trend toward better eradication.
population_specificity: Children undergoing Helicobacter pylori eradication therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a multistrain probiotic mixture, including Lactobacillus casei BGP93, in improving functional constipation and blood parameters in elderly nursing home residents.
results_summary: The probiotic mixture, including Lactobacillus casei, showed a significant increase in stool frequency after 71 days when laxative use was excluded, indicating a prolonged effect. No significant adverse effects or changes in blood parameters were observed.
population_specificity: Elderly nursing home residents (60 participants, aged 77.9 ± 8.84 years, with functional constipation).
effective_dosage: Not specified (liquid formulation containing Bifidobacterium animalis subsp. lactis BLC1, Lactobacillus acidophilus LA3, and Lactobacillus casei BGP93).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of fermented soymilk-honey made with different probiotics, including Lactobacillus Casei, on osteocalcin levels in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Lactobacillus Casei's effects on osteocalcin levels, only stating that the study aimed to investigate this relationship.
population_specificity: 54 postmenopausal women divided into three intervention groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Lactobacillus casei oral supplementation on episiotomy wound healing in primiparous women.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus casei significantly improved wound healing compared to placebo, with lower wound healing scores (indicating better healing) at 5 and 15 days postpartum in the probiotic group. The adjusted mean difference was statistically significant (P=0.03).
population_specificity: Primiparous women with mediolateral episiotomy (incision length ≤5 cm) in Iran.
effective_dosage: 1.5 * 10^9 CFU of Lactobacillus casei 431 (frequency not specified).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but outcomes were measured at 5±1 and 15±1 days postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the substrate specificity and activity of the bacterial α-l-fucosidase AlfC from Lactobacillus casei with other fucosidases, particularly its ability to remove core fucose from glycoproteins.
results_summary: The study found that AlfC from Lactobacillus casei could not remove core fucose from intact full-length N-glycopeptides or N-glycoproteins but could hydrolyze only truncated Fucα1,6GlcNAc-peptide substrates, showing limited efficacy compared to human α-l-fucosidase (FucA1).
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of probiotic Lactobacillus strains, including Lactobacillus Casei, as an alternative therapy for allergic rhinitis and asthma by reviewing current studies.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus species, including Lactobacillus Casei, provided symptom relief and improved quality of life in allergic rhinitis patients, with changes in cytokine profiles and reduced allergy-related immunoglobulins. However, the exact mechanism of immune modulation remains unclear.
population_specificity: Children and adults suffering from allergic rhinitis or asthma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of Lactobacillus casei in enhancing anti-coronavirus vaccine efficacy and its benefits for diabetes.
results_summary: The study suggested that Lactobacillus casei, along with other probiotics, could serve as vectors for delivering or enhancing anti-coronavirus vaccines and may be beneficial for diabetes, though no direct proof of benefits for COVID-19 infection was provided.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes and potential COVID-19 infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a probiotic product containing Lactobacillus casei Zhang as an adjunct to a routine regimen in managing irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: The probiotic group showed significant reductions in IBS symptom severity, serum inflammatory markers (IL-6, TNF-α), and harmful bacterial genera, though some beneficial genera also decreased. Clinical improvement was linked to gut microbiota modulation, and initial microbiome composition influenced outcomes.
population_specificity: 45 patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a probiotic mixture containing Lactobacillus casei (TMC) in improving lipid profiles and intestinal function in mild hypercholesterolemic volunteers.
results_summary: The probiotic mixture significantly improved fecal weight, gastrointestinal transit time, and beneficial gut microbiota while reducing total cholesterol (8.1%) and LDL-c (10.4%). It also increased the lag time of LDL oxidation, indicating cardioprotective effects.
population_specificity: 40 healthy mild hypercholesterolemic subjects (180-220 mg/dL).
effective_dosage: 30 g of probiotic-contained milk formula mixed with 200 mL of water, daily.
study_duration: 10 weeks of intervention followed by 2 weeks of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of genetically modified lactic acid bacteria (LAB), including Lactobacillus Casei, as mucosal HPV vaccines to induce immune responses against HPV-associated cervical cancer.
results_summary: The study found that LAB-based HPV vaccines, particularly those expressing surface-anchored antigens, show promise in inducing systemic and mucosal cytotoxic immune responses. The review highlights key factors for improving protein yield and immune response in therapeutic HPV vaccine development.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of international studies from 2000-2020)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of fermented milk containing Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota (LcS) on the incidence of constipation, diarrhea, acute respiratory infections (ARI), and nutritional status in young Vietnamese children.
results_summary: The probiotic drink significantly reduced the incidence of constipation and ARI, showed a trend toward reducing diarrhea, and improved weight gain compared to the control group. No effects were observed on the duration of diarrhea or ARI.
population_specificity: 1003 Vietnamese children aged 3-5 years in Thanh Hoa province.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the potential health maintenance benefits of long-term lactic acid bacteria-based probiotics, specifically in relation to weight loss in the elderly.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Lactobacillus Casei's effects, only mentioning the study's observational nature and its focus on health maintenance.
population_specificity: Elderly participants from a previous clinical study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the treatment efficacy of Lactobacillus Casei for vestibular migraine (VM).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Lactobacillus Casei's effects on VM, only stating that its effect on VM is not clear.
population_specificity: Patients with vestibular migraine (VM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the comparative effectiveness of different probiotic strains, including Lactobacillus casei, in treating pediatric atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei DN-114001 showed potential in reducing atopic dermatitis symptoms based on low certainty evidence (SMD -1.35). Another mix containing Lactobacillus casei (Mix6) demonstrated moderate efficacy (SMD -0.85).
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low- and high-dose multi-strain probiotic supplements containing Lactobacillus Casei in the general adult population.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Lactobacillus Casei's effects, only stating the study's aim to compare dosage responses.
population_specificity: General adult population

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Lactobacillus casei cell wall extract (LCWE) in studying Kawasaki disease (KD) pathophysiology and advancing treatment strategies.
results_summary: The study found that LCWE-induced KD vasculitis in a mouse model accelerated research into KD pathophysiology and supported clinical trials for IL-1R antagonist (Anakinra) as a treatment. LCWE contributed to understanding novel genetic risk factors and combination therapies for refractory KD.
population_specificity: Mouse model (not human subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent literature on the efficacy of probiotics, including Lactobacillus Casei, against pathogens causing wound infections.
results_summary: The study found that probiotics can aid in skin healing by stimulating immune cell production and exhibit antagonistic effects against pathogens through competitive exclusion. Fourteen studies were reviewed, supporting these mechanisms.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the role of IL-1 signaling in sex-based differences in Kawasaki disease (KD) susceptibility, not Lactobacillus Casei.
results_summary: The study found that IL-1β may mediate sex-based differences in KD, suggesting implications for anti-IL-1β therapies, but did not examine Lactobacillus Casei.
population_specificity: Children with Kawasaki disease (KD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Lactobacillus casei in preventing Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) and antibiotic-associated diarrhea (AAD) compared to other probiotics and placebo.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei was the most effective probiotic intervention, significantly reducing the incidence rates of CDAD (OR 0.19) and AAD (OR 0.32) compared to placebo. It also ranked highest in reducing diarrhea duration and delaying onset.
population_specificity: 4,692 patients from randomized controlled trials (RCTs) evaluating probiotic interventions for CDAD and AAD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily oral Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) could improve CD4+ T-cell counts, CD4+/CD8+ ratio, immune activation, and intestinal microbiome composition in HIV-infected patients on suppressive ART with poor CD4+ recovery.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant effect of LcS on CD4+ T-cell counts, CD4+/CD8+ ratio, immune activation markers, or intestinal microbiome composition at 6 or 12 weeks compared to placebo.
population_specificity: HIV-infected patients on suppressive ART with poor CD4+ recovery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of synbiotic supplementation (including Lactobacillus casei) on anthropometric indices, metabolic markers, and psychological status in adults with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotic supplementation significantly improved body weight, total cholesterol, triglycerides, LDL-C, stress, anxiety, and depression, but had no significant effect on HDL-C, blood pressure, fasting glucose, insulin, BMI, or waist circumference.
population_specificity: Adults with overweight or obesity (39 men and 20 women).
effective_dosage: 500 mg capsule (containing Lactobacillus casei, Lactobacillus acidophilus, Bifidobacterium bifidum, and inulin) daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily consumption of Lactobacillus casei could prevent gastrointestinal adverse events caused by anti-tuberculosis (TB) drugs.
results_summary: Both high and low doses of L. casei reduced the incidence and duration of anti-TB-associated gastrointestinal adverse events compared to the control group, with higher doses showing better effects for vomiting and appetite loss.
population_specificity: 429 adult patients undergoing intensive-phase anti-TB therapy.
effective_dosage: One bottle (10 billion CFU) per day (low-dose) or two bottles (20 billion CFU) per day (high-dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of BLS-M07 (containing Lactobacillus Casei expressing HPV16 E7 antigen) as a non-surgical treatment for CIN 3 by assessing immune response and pathological regression.
results_summary: BLS-M07 demonstrated safety with no severe adverse events, improved RCI grading, and increased HPV16 E7 antibody production. In phase 2a, 75% of CIN 3 patients were cured.
population_specificity: Patients with CIN 3 (cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 3).
effective_dosage: 500 mg, 1,000 mg, and 1,500 mg administered orally 5 times a week on weeks 1, 2, 4, and 8 (phase 1); 1,000 mg in phase 2a.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) administration could accelerate hand function recovery in senior patients with acute distal radius fractures.
results_summary: The study found that patients receiving LcS showed significantly faster improvement in Michigan Hand Questionnaire scores, radial deviation and inclination, and ulnar deviation and variance compared to the placebo group over the 3-month intervention period.
population_specificity: Senior patients diagnosed with acute distal radius fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of ora-pro-nobis flour on the adhesion of Lactobacillus casei to intestinal epithelial cells and its effects on gastrointestinal symptoms and metabolic parameters in overweight men.
results_summary: The study found that ora-pro-nobis flour did not affect Lactobacillus casei adhesion to Caco-2 cells but improved gastrointestinal symptoms and satiety while maintaining high adherence of L. casei to intestinal cells and stable anthropometric and biochemical parameters.
population_specificity: Overweight men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and efficacy of a probiotic mixture containing Lactobacillus casei in reducing pro-inflammatory cytokines in colorectal cancer patients post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found that the probiotic mixture significantly reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-10, IL-12, IL-17A, IL-17C, IL-22) in colorectal cancer patients, with no significant difference in IFN-γ levels. No surgical infections or antibiotic requirements were reported.
population_specificity: Fifty-two colorectal cancer patients, four weeks post-surgery, with ~70% in Duke's C stage.
effective_dosage: 30 billion CFU of a six-strain mixture, taken orally twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether probiotic supplementation, including Lactobacillus Casei, modulates gut microbiota and its association with obesity and cardiometabolic risk factors.
results_summary: The probiotic mixture influenced gut microbiota composition, reducing TM7 (associated with adiposity) and increasing Clostridiaceae (linked to lower TNF-α). TM7 was more prevalent in subjects with higher adiposity, suggesting its role as a potential target for obesity treatment.
population_specificity: Subjects with obesity and cardiometabolic risk factors (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Lactobacillus casei in petit-suisse cheese on the oral microbiota of children.
results_summary: The study assessed the feasibility of adding Lactobacillus casei to petit-suisse over 28 days and monitored changes in saliva microbiota before, during, and after consumption. Lactic bacteria remained viable, but specific efficacy outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Lactobacillus Casei (Lc) on clinical symptoms, intestinal microbiota, and inflammatory markers in children with acute diarrhea.
results_summary: The study found that Lc increased fecal IgA levels and downregulated fecal lactoferrin and calprotectin, suggesting reduced intestinal inflammation and improved immune response during acute diarrhea.
population_specificity: Children with acute diarrhea (specific age range not provided in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential role of probiotics, particularly Lactobacillus casei, in preventing and treating breast cancer, as well as alleviating chemotherapy-induced side effects.
results_summary: In vitro and animal studies showed Lactobacillus casei induced cancer cell apoptosis, inhibited tumor growth, and exhibited immunomodulatory effects. Human studies suggested reduced breast cancer incidence with Lactobacillus casei consumption, but no curative role was confirmed.
population_specificity: Human, animal, and in vitro studies (no specific human subpopulation detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of synbiotic supplementation, including Lactobacillus Casei, on metabolic profiles in diabetic patients undergoing hemodialysis.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotic supplementation, containing Lactobacillus Casei, improved metabolic profiles in diabetic hemodialysis patients, though specific results for Lactobacillus Casei alone were not detailed.
population_specificity: Diabetic patients undergoing hemodialysis (n=60).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the sensitivity of Lactobacillus casei to photodynamic therapy (photosensitization) compared to other cariogenic bacteria in both planktonic and biofilm forms.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus casei showed significant reductions in viability (30% in planktonic form, 13% in sessile form) when exposed to photodynamic therapy, indicating it was effectively targeted by the treatment. The effect was comparable to other cariogens except Streptococcus salivarius, which was minimally affected.
population_specificity: Human dentine biofilms and planktonic bacterial cultures.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exposure to Toluidine blue O and 1-minute laser treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of probiotic supplementation, including Lactobacillus Casei, on genetic and metabolic profiles in patients with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) not on oral hypoglycemic agents.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic supplementation improved genetic and metabolic profiles in GDM patients, though specific outcomes for Lactobacillus Casei alone were not detailed. The results suggest a beneficial effect of the probiotic blend.
population_specificity: 48 patients with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) not on oral hypoglycemic agents.
effective_dosage: 2 × 10^9 CFU per capsule (combined with other probiotics).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus Casei, in combination with isoflavones, could improve genitourinary symptoms in postmenopausal women compared to hormone therapy.
results_summary: The study found that probiotics (including Lactobacillus Casei) improved the metabolism of isoflavones but did not significantly relieve urogenital symptoms or produce an estrogenic effect on the urogenital tract.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women aged 40-60 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified for Lactobacillus Casei individually; administered as part of a multi-strain probiotic blend.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of oral administration of Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) on pain relief in patients with single rib fractures.
results_summary: Patients receiving LcS experienced more effective pain relief during deep breathing, coughing, and turning over compared to placebo, along with a larger increase in SMI lung volume. Sleep quality did not significantly improve after 1 month of LcS treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with a single rib fracture.
effective_dosage: Skimmed milk containing commercial probiotic LcS, administered daily (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of a synbiotic supplement containing Lactobacillus casei on improving atopic dermatitis symptoms in children.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in AD symptoms, with reductions in SCORAD index, pruritus, and sleep disturbance scores. Higher baseline severity and adherence were predictive of greater improvement.
population_specificity: 320 children aged 0-12 years with atopic dermatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether synbiotics containing Lactobacillus casei could modulate gut microbiota and reduce infectious complications in mechanically ventilated sepsis patients.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics significantly reduced the incidence of enteritis and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and increased fecal Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus counts, but did not affect bacteremia or mortality.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated sepsis patients in the ICU.
effective_dosage: Daily synbiotics (Bifidobacterium breve strain Yakult, Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota, and galactooligosaccharides).
study_duration: Administered within 3 days of admission and continued for up to 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether yogurt supplemented with Lactobacillus casei subsp. casei Lc-01, in combination with other probiotics, could prevent antibiotic-associated diarrhea in hospitalized patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in diarrhea rates between the probiotic and placebo groups, indicating that Lactobacillus casei, combined with other strains, did not effectively prevent antibiotic-associated diarrhea. All-cause mortality and diarrhea duration were also similar across groups.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients (mean age 76 years) starting antibiotic treatment.
effective_dosage: 200 mL daily of probiotic yogurt containing Lactobacillus casei subsp. casei Lc-01, administered within 48 hours of antibiotic initiation and continued for up to 5 days after stopping antibiotics.
study_duration: Intervention lasted from antibiotic initiation until 5 days post-antibiotic cessation, with follow-up for 1 month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of probiotic yogurt containing Lactobacillus casei DN001, along with a low-calorie diet, on serum adipokine concentrations (omentin-1, adropin, and nesfatin-1) in obese and overweight individuals.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic yogurt with Lactobacillus casei DN001, combined with a low-calorie diet, influenced serum adipokine concentrations, though specific results for Lactobacillus casei alone were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Obese or overweight individuals aged 20-50 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (probiotic yogurt containing Lactobacillus casei DN001 was used, but exact dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether synbiotics therapy (including Lactobacillus Casei) had a preventive association against septic complications in mechanically ventilated critically ill patients.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics therapy significantly reduced the incidence of enteritis and pneumonia but did not affect bacteremia rates. The odds ratios for diarrhea-free and pneumonia-free days were significantly higher in the synbiotics group.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated critically ill patients.
effective_dosage: Not specified (synbiotics included Bifidobacterium breve, Lactobacillus casei, and galactooligosaccharides, administered within 3 days of admission).
study_duration: Evaluated over the first 28 days after admission.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Lactobacillus casei on glycemic control and serum levels of SIRT1 and fetuin-A in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei supplementation significantly reduced fasting blood sugar, insulin concentration, and insulin resistance, and increased SIRT1 while decreasing fetuin-A levels, improving glycemic response in T2DM patients.
population_specificity: Forty patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (20 in the intervention group, 20 in the placebo group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical efficacy and safety of a probiotic formulation containing Lactobacillus casei LBC80R for preventing Clostridium difficile infection (CDI) in healthcare settings.
results_summary: The study found that the probiotic formulation, including Lactobacillus casei, demonstrated efficacy in reducing CDI incidence rates, supported by randomized controlled trials and facility-level interventions. It also highlighted an excellent safety and tolerability profile.
population_specificity: Patients receiving antibiotics in healthcare settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of probiotic treatments, including Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota, on patients with fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS) or chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota reduced anxiety scores and altered fecal composition in CFS patients after 8 weeks of treatment. The probiotic demonstrated significant effects on modulating anxiety and inflammatory processes.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether perioperative administration of symbiotics, including Lactobacillus Casei, reduces surgical wound infection rates in colorectal cancer surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found that symbiotics significantly reduced surgical site infections (2% vs. 21.4% in the placebo group) and other postoperative infections (none in the symbiotics group vs. multiple in the control group).
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer patients undergoing elective surgery.
effective_dosage: Lactobacillus Casei 10^8 to 10^9 CFU, administered alongside other probiotics and FOS for five days pre-surgery and 14 days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of synbiotic supplementation, including Lactobacillus casei, on glycemic control and lipid profiles in women with PCOS.
results_summary: The study evaluated synbiotic supplementation's impact but did not isolate Lactobacillus casei's specific effects; overall, it aimed to improve glycemic and lipid outcomes in PCOS patients.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
effective_dosage: Not specified (synbiotic capsule contained multiple strains, dosage not detailed in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fermented soymilk with Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) on skin condition, gut microbiota, and isoflavone bioavailability in healthy premenopausal women.
results_summary: Both fermented soymilk (FSM) with LcS and regular soymilk (SM) improved skin condition and increased urinary isoflavone levels, but only FSM significantly modified gut microbiota by increasing Lactobacillaceae and reducing Enterobacteriaceae and Porphyromonadaceae.
population_specificity: Healthy premenopausal Japanese women (n=60).
effective_dosage: Twice daily for 8 weeks (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether symbiotics containing Lactobacillus Casei improved nutritional status, biochemical data, and intestinal function in patients with chronic pancreatitis.
results_summary: The study found that symbiotics significantly improved hemoglobin, hematocrit, red blood cells, total lymphocyte count, serum magnesium, and albumin levels while reducing total serum cholesterol. No significant changes were observed in nutritional status for either group.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic pancreatitis (60 participants).
effective_dosage: 12 g/day of symbiotics (containing Lactobacillus Casei, Lactobacillus rhamnosus, Lactobacillus acidophilus, Bifidobacterium bifidum, and fructooligosaccharides).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a probiotic mixture containing Lactobacillus casei CECT 9104 is safe and effective in reducing atopic dermatitis symptoms and topical steroid use in children.
results_summary: The probiotic mixture significantly reduced the SCORAD index by 83% in the treatment group compared to 24% in the placebo group and decreased topical steroid use by 7.7% versus 10.8% in controls.
population_specificity: Children aged 4 to 17 years with moderate atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: 10^9 total colony-forming units daily (combined with Bifidobacterium lactis CECT 8145 and B. longum CECT 7347).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multi-strain probiotic supplement, including Lactobacillus Casei, could improve circulating endotoxin levels and cardiometabolic biomarkers in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in endotoxin levels between the probiotics and placebo groups. However, the probiotics group showed a modest improvement in waist-to-hip ratio (WHR) and a clinically significant improvement in HOMA-IR, indicating better insulin sensitivity.
population_specificity: 78 adult Saudi patients with T2DM who were medication-naïve and without comorbidities.
effective_dosage: 2.5 × 10^9 CFU twice daily (specific strain breakdown not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Lactobacillus, including Lactobacillus Casei, on weight loss and/or fat mass in overweight adults.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus Casei, when combined with phenolic compounds, showed beneficial effects on weight loss and/or fat mass, though results were strain-dependent. Some studies reported no effect or weight gain, indicating variability in outcomes.
population_specificity: Overweight adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of Lactobacillus acidophilus CL1285, Lactobacillus casei LBC80R, and Lactobacillus rhamnosus CLR2 could relieve symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study compared the probiotic combination to placebo in 113 subjects over 12 weeks, but the abstract does not specify the exact outcomes regarding Lactobacillus casei's effects on IBS symptoms.
population_specificity: 113 subjects with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) across 3 clinical sites.
effective_dosage: 2 capsules containing 50×10^9 CFU (exact dosage per strain not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of synbiotic supplementation, including Lactobacillus casei, on carotid intima-media thickness (CIMT), inflammation, and oxidative stress in individuals with overweight, diabetes, and coronary heart disease (CHD).
results_summary: The study assessed synbiotic supplementation's impact on CIMT, inflammation, and oxidative stress, but specific results for Lactobacillus casei alone were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 50-85 with overweight, diabetes, and CHD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of probiotic supplementation, including Lactobacillus casei, on gene expression related to inflammation, insulin, and lipids in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Probiotic supplementation significantly down-regulated gene expression of IL-8 and TNF-α but had no significant effect on IL-1, PPAR-γ, or LDLR in MS patients.
population_specificity: 40 patients with multiple sclerosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) on pain, inflammation, and functional outcomes in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: LcS significantly improved WOMAC and VAS scores and reduced serum hs-CRP levels compared to placebo, suggesting it may be a therapeutic option for knee OA by reducing inflammation.
population_specificity: 537 patients with knee osteoarthritis
effective_dosage: Skimmed milk containing LcS daily (exact dosage not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Lactobacillus casei as a probiotic supplement in triple therapy for improving H. pylori eradication rates and reducing side effects in pediatric patients.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei was identified as the best probiotic for increasing H. pylori eradication rates (P score = 0.84) and was part of multi-strain combinations effective in reducing specific side effects like diarrhea and taste disturbance.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with Helicobacter pylori infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota (LcS)-containing beverages on intestinal microbiota, organic acid levels, and body weight in obese children.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in fecal Bifidobacterium levels in obese children compared to controls. After a 6-month intervention with LcS beverages alongside diet and exercise, body weight and serological markers were monitored, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Obese children (average age 10.8 years, BMI Z score 2.7±1.7) and non-obese controls (average age 8.5 years, BMI Z score 0.1±0.7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a probiotic mixture containing Lactobacillus casei could reduce the duration of blood in diarrhea and hospitalization in patients with acute dysentery.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic consumers had significantly shorter durations of blood in diarrhea (2.62 vs. 3.16 days) and hospitalization (3.16 vs. 3.66 days) compared to the control group, suggesting effectiveness in reducing dysentery symptoms.
population_specificity: Patients with acute dysentery
effective_dosage: High amounts of 7-strain probiotics (Kidilact® sachet) daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of probiotic supplementation, including Lactobacillus Casei, on inflammation, oxidative stress, and pregnancy outcomes in women with gestational diabetes.
results_summary: Probiotic supplementation significantly improved fasting plasma glucose, reduced inflammation (hs-CRP), and enhanced antioxidant capacity (TAC) while lowering oxidative stress markers (MDA), but did not affect pregnancy outcomes.
population_specificity: 60 women with gestational diabetes not on oral hypoglycemic agents.
effective_dosage: 2 × 10^9 CFU/day (combined with Lactobacillus acidophilus and Bifidobacterium bifidum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of Lactobacillus casei rhamnosus Lcr35 in managing functional constipation in children under 5 years.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in treatment success between the Lcr35 and placebo groups. Both groups showed increased defecation frequency, but the placebo group had significantly greater improvement than the Lcr35 group.
population_specificity: Children under 5 years with functional constipation (Rome III criteria).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of probiotics, particularly Lactobacillus casei rhamnosus (LCA), on the prevention of respiratory tract infections (RTIs) in children and adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that LCA was the only probiotic effective in reducing the rate of RTIs compared to placebo, with a relative risk of 0.38. However, network analysis showed no superior effect of LCA compared to other probiotic strains in indirect analysis.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of probiotic supplementation (including Lactobacillus Casei) on glycemic control, lipid concentrations, and biomarkers of inflammation and oxidative stress in diabetic hemodialysis patients.
results_summary: Probiotic supplementation significantly improved fasting plasma glucose, serum insulin, insulin resistance, and antioxidant capacity while reducing inflammation and oxidative stress markers compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 60 diabetic patients on hemodialysis, matched by sex, dialysis duration, diabetes duration, BMI, and age.
effective_dosage: Not specified (capsule containing Lactobacillus acidophilus, Lactobacillus casei, and Bifidobacterium bifidum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a synbiotic preparation containing Lactobacillus casei on the duration of diarrhea in children compared to zinc and standard therapy.
results_summary: The synbiotic preparation significantly reduced the duration of diarrhea compared to the control group, though it was similarly effective to zinc. Zinc showed better outcomes at 72 and 96 hours.
population_specificity: Children with acute infectious diarrhea.
effective_dosage: Synbiotic preparation (specific dosage not detailed) administered for 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of a synbiotic containing Lactobacillus casei in treating functional constipation in children.
results_summary: The synbiotic group showed significant improvement in weekly defecations, abdominal pain, painful defecation, and pediatric Bristol scale compared to the placebo group, with 66.7% achieving complete benefit.
population_specificity: Children aged 4-18 years diagnosed with functional constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the scientific evidence supporting health claims for products containing Lactobacillus casei and compare published literature with corporate advertising.
results_summary: The study found insufficient scientific evidence to support health claims for Lactobacillus casei, with only 25% of included studies meeting high evidence standards (level 1b, grade A). Most studies lacked robust evidence, and corporate websites omitted some published studies.
population_specificity: Healthy human population

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of synbiotic supplementation (including Lactobacillus casei) on markers of insulin metabolism and lipid profiles in patients with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: Synbiotic supplementation significantly improved insulin sensitivity, reduced insulin resistance, and lowered serum TAG and VLDL-cholesterol concentrations in GDM patients compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 70 patients with GDM aged 18-40 years.
effective_dosage: 2×10^9 colony-forming units/g of Lactobacillus casei (combined with other strains) plus 800 mg inulin daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a fermented milk product containing Lactobacillus casei CNCM I-1518 could reduce the incidence of respiratory and gastrointestinal common infectious diseases (CIDs) in children attending day-care centers.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in overall CID incidence between the fermented milk and control groups, but a significantly lower incidence of rhinopharyngitis was observed in the Lactobacillus casei group over the entire study period. No severe cases were reported, and no differences were found in disease duration, severity, or quality-of-life measures.
population_specificity: Children aged 3 to 6 years attending day-care centers in Russia.
effective_dosage: 100 g of fermented milk product twice daily.
study_duration: 3 months of intervention followed by a 1-month observation period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of multispecies probiotic supplementation, including Lactobacillus Casei, on metabolic status in pregnant women during the first half of pregnancy.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic supplementation significantly improved markers of insulin metabolism, reduced triglycerides, and decreased inflammation and oxidative stress compared to placebo. However, changes in plasma glutathione (GSH) were not significant after adjusting for baseline levels, age, and BMI.
population_specificity: Pregnant women aged 18-37 years in the first half of pregnancy (9 weeks gestation at study start).
effective_dosage: 2 × 10^9 CFU/g each of Lactobacillus acidophilus, Lactobacillus casei, and Bifidobacterium bifidum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial potential of a dentifrice containing Eugenia uniflora extract against oral pathogens, including Lactobacillus casei, and compare its clinical efficacy to a triclosan-based dentifrice in treating gingivitis in children.
results_summary: The experimental dentifrice showed efficient antibacterial activity against Lactobacillus casei in vitro. However, the clinical trial primarily focused on gingivitis outcomes, with no specific results reported for Lactobacillus casei's effects in vivo.
population_specificity: Children aged 10-12 years with clinical signs of gingivitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of probiotic treatment (Lactobacillus casei Shirota) on functional recovery in elderly patients with distal radius fractures.
results_summary: The study found that patients receiving Lactobacillus casei Shirota showed significantly faster improvement in DASH score, pain, CRPS score, wrist flexion, and grip strength compared to placebo, achieving comparable outcomes by month 4 that placebo patients reached by month 6.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (n=417) with acute distal radius fractures.
effective_dosage: Daily administration in skimmed milk (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the health and immune benefits of consuming Lactobacillus casei Shirota in highly physically active individuals, focusing on upper respiratory tract infection symptoms and viral antibody levels.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in upper respiratory tract infection incidence, duration, or severity between the probiotic and placebo groups. However, the probiotic reduced plasma CMV and EBV antibody titres in seropositive participants, suggesting a potential immune benefit.
population_specificity: University athletes and games players (n=243).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily consumption of Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota could relieve stress-associated abdominal dysfunction and preserve gut microbiota diversity in healthy subjects under stress.
results_summary: The study found that L. casei strain Shirota significantly suppressed stress-induced increases in abdominal dysfunction, reduced gastrointestinal symptoms, preserved gut microbiota diversity, and lowered salivary cortisol levels compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Healthy medical students under examination stress conditions.
effective_dosage: Daily consumption of L. casei strain Shirota-fermented milk (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of probiotic supplementation, including Lactobacillus Casei, on clinical and metabolic outcomes in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Probiotic supplementation improved Disease Activity Score (DAS-28), reduced serum insulin levels, HOMA-B, and hs-CRP concentrations, with borderline significant effects on cholesterol levels compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis aged 25-70 years.
effective_dosage: 2 × 10(9) CFU/g of Lactobacillus Casei daily (combined with other strains).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota (LcS) could mitigate stress-induced psychological and physiological responses via gut-brain interactions.
results_summary: LcS significantly reduced stress-induced cortisol levels and physical symptoms in humans and suppressed stress-related biomarkers in rats, likely through vagal afferent signaling and reduced hypothalamic stress reactivity.
population_specificity: Healthy medical students under academic stress and rats subjected to water avoidance stress.
effective_dosage: LcS-fermented milk daily (exact dosage not specified).
study_duration: 8 weeks for humans, 2 weeks for rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of probiotic supplementation (including Lactobacillus Casei) on symptoms of depression and metabolic status in patients with major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: Probiotic supplementation significantly improved depression symptoms, reduced serum insulin levels, insulin resistance, and hs-CRP concentrations, and increased glutathione levels, but did not affect fasting glucose, lipid profiles, or total antioxidant capacity.
population_specificity: 40 patients aged 20-55 with MDD diagnosed via DSM-IV criteria.
effective_dosage: 2 × 10^9 CFU/g of Lactobacillus Casei (combined with other strains), administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily consumption of Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota (LcS) could mitigate psychological, physiological, and physical stress responses in medical students undergoing a high-stakes examination.
results_summary: The study found that LcS consumption reduced stress-related physiological markers (e.g., cortisol and L-tryptophan levels) and physical symptoms (e.g., abdominal and cold symptoms) compared to placebo, with significant improvements in faecal serotonin levels post-examination.
population_specificity: Healthy medical students preparing for a nationwide promotion examination.
effective_dosage: Fermented milk containing LcS, once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different antimicrobial therapies, including their impact on Lactobacillus casei levels in deep carious dentin lesions.
results_summary: The study found that all tested therapies effectively reduced the number of Lactobacillus casei in carious dentin, with no significant differences among the protocols. No adverse effects or restoration failures were reported.
population_specificity: 32 children aged 5 to 7 years with deep carious dentin lesions in primary molars.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) on symptoms and quality of life in IBS patients.
results_summary: After 8 weeks, LcS did not achieve a 30% improvement in symptom scores, but by week 16, the probiotic group showed a mean improvement of 34%, though this was not significantly different from the placebo group.
population_specificity: IBS patients (Rome II criteria) aged 18-65 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota-fermented milk (LcS-FM) on the incidence of upper respiratory tract infections (URTIs) in healthy middle-aged office workers.
results_summary: The study found that the incidence of URTIs was significantly lower in the LcS-FM group (22.4%) compared to the control group (53.2%), with a higher URTI-free rate over the test period, suggesting LcS-FM may reduce URTI risk through immune modulation.
population_specificity: Healthy male office workers aged 30-49 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding Lactobacillus casei DG to a levofloxacin-doxycycline triple therapy improved H. pylori eradication rates and tolerability in non-responders.
results_summary: The study found that adding Lactobacillus casei DG increased H. pylori eradication rates (55% vs. 43% per protocol) and improved tolerability, with side effects generally mild.
population_specificity: 142 non-responders (99 women, 43 men; mean age 53.0 ± 12.7 years) to previous H. pylori eradication therapies.
effective_dosage: Not specified for Lactobacillus casei DG.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a fermented milk drink containing Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) could prevent aflatoxin absorption and reduce serum aflatoxin B1-lysine adduct (AFB1-lys) and urinary aflatoxin M1 concentrations.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in aflatoxin biomarker concentrations overall, but within-group analysis showed a significant reduction in AFB1-lys concentrations in one group (Blue group) after probiotic intervention, particularly at the 2nd and 4th weeks compared to baseline and placebo.
population_specificity: Seventy-one subjects recruited from a screening stage, divided into two groups (Yellow and Blue).
study_duration: Two 4-week intervention phases with a 2-week wash-out period in between.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and clinical benefits of a probiotic formulation containing Lactobacillus casei LBC80R in reducing antibiotic-associated diarrhea and Clostridium difficile infection (CDI).
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the probiotic formulation, including Lactobacillus casei, reduced incidences of antibiotic-associated diarrhea and CDI, showed antimicrobial activity against C. difficile, and neutralized toxins A/B in vitro. The strains and products were also confirmed to be safe, stable, and capable of surviving gastrointestinal transit.
population_specificity: Human clinical trial participants (specific population details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multispecies probiotic containing Lactobacillus casei W56 could reduce cognitive reactivity to sad mood in non-depressed individuals.
results_summary: The study found that participants who received the 4-week multispecies probiotic intervention showed significantly reduced overall cognitive reactivity to sad mood, particularly in rumination and aggressive thoughts, compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: 20 healthy participants without current mood disorder (plus 20 controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effectiveness of NanoAg-IS-PMMA and NanoAg-I-PMMA in inhibiting the planktonic growth and biofilm formation of cariogenic bacteria, including Lactobacillus casei, in orthodontic patients.
results_summary: NanoAg-IS-BOA showed strong anti-biofilm effects against Lactobacillus casei, inhibiting biofilm formation by 20.1 to 79.9% compared to the control. NanoAg-IS-BOA demonstrated higher antibacterial activity than NanoAg-I-BOA throughout the trial.
population_specificity: 24 patients aged 7-15 years harboring cariogenic bacteria, including Lactobacillus casei.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Lactobacillus casei Shirota in preventing antibiotic-associated diarrhoea (AAD) and Clostridium difficile diarrhoea (CDD) in older patients.
results_summary: The study found no preventive effect of Lactobacillus casei Shirota for AAD and CDD in older patients, aligning with the overall conclusion that probiotics may not reduce the risk of these conditions in this population.
population_specificity: Older patients (age ≥65 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Lactobacillus casei 01 supplementation on oxidative stress indices in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of L. casei 01 supplementation on oxidative stress markers (MDA, TAC, CAT, SOD, GPx) in RA patients compared to placebo. SOD activity decreased in the probiotic group, and GPx activity decreased in both groups, but no significant between-group differences were observed.
population_specificity: 46 patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding probiotics (including Lactobacillus casei) to standard triple therapy improves H. pylori eradication rates or reduces side effects in children.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in H. pylori eradication rates (66.6% with probiotics vs. 68.9% without) or side effects between the groups, suggesting probiotics did not enhance treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Symptomatic children aged 7-18 years with H. pylori infection.
effective_dosage: Not specified (probiotics included Lactobacillus casei, Lactobacillus acidophilus, and Bifidobacterium lactis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether synbiotics containing Lactobacillus casei could reduce postoperative complications, infections, and mortality in patients undergoing surgery for periampullary neoplasms.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics significantly reduced postoperative infections, antibiotic use, noninfectious complications, hospital stay, and mortality compared to placebo. Lactobacillus casei was part of the synbiotic formulation that demonstrated these benefits.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing surgery for periampullary neoplasms.
effective_dosage: 1 × 10^9 CFU of Lactobacillus casei, twice daily, as part of a synbiotic blend.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether probiotic Lactobacillus casei Shirota could reduce mutans streptococci counts in saliva, potentially aiding in dental caries prevention.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant reduction (34%) in mutans streptococci colony counts in children consuming probiotic milk (p=.003), suggesting its effectiveness in lowering caries-related bacteria.
population_specificity: 31 children in a double-blinded study.
effective_dosage: Not specified (probiotic milk administered for 10 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the prophylactic efficacy of Lactobacillus casei rhamnosus against neomycin for preventing recurrent cholangitis in biliary atresia patients post-Kasai operation.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei rhamnosus was as effective as neomycin in preventing cholangitis (20% incidence vs. 80% in controls) and improved weight gain. Stool cultures showed increased Lactobacillus and decreased Escherichia coli populations.
population_specificity: Jaundice-free biliary atresia patients aged 0-3 years who underwent Kasai operation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily intake of Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) reduces colonization of pathogens (streptococci and Staphylococcus aureus) in the nose and throat of healthy volunteers with low natural killer cell activity and influences salivary secretory immunoglobulin A (SIgA) production.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant effect of LcS on the incidence of Staph. aureus or streptococci in the nasal or pharyngeal spaces, nor did it affect salivary SIgA production. The intervention did not influence nasopharyngeal colonization with Gram-positive potential pathogens.
population_specificity: Healthy human volunteers with low natural killer cell activity.
effective_dosage: Not specified (fermented milk drink with LcS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-efficiency and effectiveness of Lactobacillus casei DN 114001 in reducing antibiotic-associated diarrhea (AAD) compared to another Lactobacillus casei strain (Shirota).
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus casei DN 114001 significantly reduced AAD incidence (6.5% vs. 28.4%) and shortened its duration, with notable cost savings. The other tested strain (Shirota) showed no advantages.
population_specificity: 258 patients with infections in a primary care hospital in western Germany (107 received probiotics).
effective_dosage: At least 10 billion cultures of Lactobacillus casei DN 114001 twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether conditioning intestinal dendritic cells (DC) with Lactobacillus casei Shirota could restore normal function in ulcerative colitis (UC) patients by modulating T-cell responses.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei Shirota partially restored normal DC function in UC patients, reducing Toll-like receptor 2/4 expression and restoring the ability to imprint homing molecules on T cells and generate interleukin-22 production. This suggests that probiotic conditioning of DC may indirectly improve T-cell dysfunction in UC.
population_specificity: Humans with ulcerative colitis (UC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota (LcS) on stool consistency, constipation-related symptoms, quality of life, and haemorrhoid incidence in postpartum women.
results_summary: The probiotic group showed improved scores for constipation-related symptoms and quality of life compared to placebo, with earlier recovery from haemorrhoids. No significant effect was observed on stool consistency or frequency, and no adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Women during puerperium (postpartum period) who had natural childbirth.
effective_dosage: One bottle/day of fermented milk containing at least 6.5×10^9 cfu of LcS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus casei DN-114001 improves H. pylori eradication rates and reduces side effects when used alongside antibiotic therapy.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus casei DN-114001 significantly increased H. pylori eradication rates, particularly when antibiotic therapies were relatively ineffective. However, its impact on reducing side effects was inconclusive and only observed in non-blinded trials.
population_specificity: 4,459 patients across 33 randomized controlled trials, focusing on H. pylori eradication therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and clinical efficacy of an attenuated Lactobacillus casei expressing HPV16 E7 protein in patients with HPV16-associated CIN3.
results_summary: The study found that oral administration of the vaccine increased E7-specific mucosal immunity in cervical lesions, with 70% of patients on the optimized dose experiencing a pathological down-grade to CIN2. No adverse events were reported, and E7-CMI responses correlated with clinical improvement.
population_specificity: Patients with HPV16-associated cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 3 (CIN3).

study_goal: The researchers investigated whether a probiotic preparation containing Lactobacillus Casei was associated with Vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus (VRE) colonization in preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic use and vancomycin exposure were significant risk factors for VRE colonization, suggesting that probiotics may mediate the acquisition and transfer of resistance genes. The outbreak's timing coincided with the probiotic trial, raising safety concerns.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with gestational age less than 32 weeks.
effective_dosage: Not specified (probiotic preparation included multiple strains and compounds).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Lactobacillus Casei Shirota on gut transit time, stool output, and constipation symptoms in adults with functional constipation.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus Casei Shirota did not significantly improve stool frequency (WMD: -0.2 bowel movements/wk) or stool consistency (SMD: +0.26) compared to controls. No serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Adults with functional constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of a synbiotic containing Lactobacillus casei and other probiotic strains in reducing infant crying time due to colic.
results_summary: The synbiotic group showed significantly higher treatment success (reduction in crying time >50%) and symptom resolution (reduction >90%) compared to placebo at day 7 and day 30, with no reported complications.
population_specificity: Breastfed infants aged 15-120 days with infantile colic.
effective_dosage: 1 billion CFU per sachet, administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Lactobacillus casei 01 supplementation on symptoms and inflammatory biomarkers in women with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: L. casei 01 supplementation reduced hs-CRP levels, tender and swollen joint counts, global health score, and DAS28, while improving inflammatory cytokines (IL-10, IL-12, TNF-α) and EULAR response rates compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Female RA patients aged 20-80 with BMI <40 and stable medication use for 3 months prior.
effective_dosage: 10^8 CFU per capsule, daily for 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if probiotic yogurt containing Lactobacillus casei DN001, combined with a weight-loss diet, could reduce proinflammatory markers and improve metabolic outcomes in overweight and obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic yogurt with a low-calorie diet (PLCD) led to significant reductions in BMI, fat percentage, leptin levels, and ROR-γt gene expression compared to other groups. However, TNF-α expression remained unchanged, and hs-CRP reduction was more evident in the group consuming probiotic yogurt without a diet (PWLCD).
population_specificity: Healthy overweight and obese individuals (n = 75).
effective_dosage: 200 g/day of yogurt containing Lactobacillus casei DN001 (10^8 CFU/g), along with Lactobacillus acidophilus La5 and Bifidobacterium BB12.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review how probiotics, including Lactobacillus casei Shirota, stimulate the immune system and their potential immunomodulatory effects.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus casei Shirota, among other probiotics, can enhance nonspecific cellular immune responses, including macrophage and NK cell activation, and modulate cytokine production in a strain-specific and dose-dependent manner. Probiotic supplementation in infancy and pregnancy may influence immune parameters and prevent immune-mediated diseases.
population_specificity: General population, with specific mentions of infants and pregnant women.

study_goal: To determine the effectiveness of two different doses of Lactobacillus Casei Shirota (LcS) in reducing urea concentrations by at least 10% in patients with stage 3 and 4 chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease (>10%) in blood urea concentrations in patients treated with the higher dose (16 x 10^9 CFU) of LcS compared to baseline measurements. No significant effect was observed with the lower dose (8 x 10^9 CFU).
population_specificity: Outpatients with stage 3 and 4 CKD treated at the National Institute of Medical Sciences and Nutrition Salvador Zubirán in Mexico.
effective_dosage: Group A: 8 x 10^9 CFU; Group B: 16 x 10^9 CFU.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota (LcS)-fermented milk could normalize bowel movements and improve infection control in elderly residents and staff of elderly care facilities.
results_summary: The study found that LcS-fermented milk significantly reduced fever incidence, improved bowel movements, increased beneficial bacteria (Bifidobacterium and Lactobacillus), decreased harmful bacteria (Clostridium difficile), and elevated fecal acetic acid and total acidity compared to placebo. Similar benefits were observed in staff members.
population_specificity: Elderly residents (average age 85) and staff members (average age 37) of elderly care facilities.
