study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether probiotic supplementation with Lactobacillus casei (Shirota strain) could reduce antibiotic-associated diarrhea (AAD) in elderly patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in AAD incidence or duration between the Lactobacillus casei group (12.2% diarrhea) and the placebo group (8.7% diarrhea), with mean durations of 4 and 5 days, respectively. The low prevalence of AAD limited the study's ability to detect potential benefits.
population_specificity: Elderly patients (66-101 years old) admitted to Geriatric Evaluation Management wards.
effective_dosage: Not specified (active Yakult product used, but exact dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Not specified (study conducted during August-October 2009, but intervention duration unclear).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize human clinical trials on Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota (LcS) for cancer prevention and discuss its immunomodulatory mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that LcS has potential benefits in preventing immune-related diseases, including cancer, supported by science-based evidence. It also discusses possible immunomodulatory mechanisms for its anti-cancer activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human clinical trials)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Lactobacillus casei 01 supplementation on disease activity and inflammatory cytokines in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus casei 01 significantly reduced disease activity and decreased proinflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-12) while increasing the regulatory cytokine IL-10 in RA patients.
population_specificity: 46 patients with rheumatoid arthritis.
effective_dosage: Minimum of 10^8 CFU of Lactobacillus casei 01 daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial activity of Lactobacillus casei against MRSA and its potential efficacy in decolonization or treatment of S. aureus infections.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei demonstrated in vitro antibacterial activity against MRSA, mediated by competitive exclusion and production of inhibitory substances. However, in vivo efficacy varied, with some strains showing effectiveness in animal models while others did not.
population_specificity: Clinical MRSA isolates and animal models (mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Lactobacillus, specifically Lactobacillus casei, in preventing Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that Lactobacillus, particularly a combination of L. acidophilus and L. casei, significantly reduced the risk of CDAD (RR 0.05, 95% CI 0.01-0.36). Single regimens of other Lactobacillus strains did not show significant effects.
population_specificity: Subjects aged 4.15 to 64.75 years, with male proportions ranging from 42.0% to 59.1%.
effective_dosage: Total daily dose ranged from 1.2×10^9 to 1.2×10^12 CFU.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of probiotic yogurt containing Lactobacillus casei DN001 on immune-related gene expression in overweight and obese individuals, both with and without a low-calorie diet.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic yogurt with Lactobacillus casei DN001, especially when combined with a low-calorie diet, significantly reduced ROR-γt and T-bet gene expression while increasing FOXP3 expression. IFN-γ expression decreased across all groups, but TNF-α, TGF-β, and GATA3 expression remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese individuals (BMI 25-35)
effective_dosage: 200 g/day of yogurt containing Lactobacillus casei DN001 (10^8 CFU/g)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of self-ligating brackets and conventional brackets on dental plaque retention and microbial flora, including Lactobacillus casei.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in Lactobacillus casei levels between self-ligating and conventional brackets. All microorganisms, including L. casei, showed significant increases from baseline to 3 months after bonding in both groups.
population_specificity: Twenty boys with a mean age of 14.2 ± 1.5 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) in reducing antibiotic-associated diarrhoea (AAD) and Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhoea (CDAD) in spinal cord injury (SCI) patients, and to evaluate undernutrition and proton pump inhibitors (PPI) as risk factors.
results_summary: The LcS group had a significantly lower incidence of AAD (17.1% vs. 54.9%, P<0.001). Undernutrition and PPI use were associated with AAD, but no significant difference in nutrient intake was observed between groups. Poor appetite and no probiotic use were identified as independent risk factors for AAD.
population_specificity: Hospitalized spinal cord injury (SCI) patients requiring antibiotics.
effective_dosage: At least 6.5 × 10⁹ live Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) once daily.
study_duration: Duration of antibiotic course plus 7 days thereafter.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of Lactobacillus casei subsp. DG, alone or in combination with mesalazine, in maintaining remission of symptomatic uncomplicated diverticular disease (SUDD).
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus casei subsp. DG, particularly when combined with mesalazine, significantly reduced recurrence rates of SUDD compared to placebo. The combination group (LM) had no recurrences, while the Lactobacillus-only group (L) had a 14.5% recurrence rate, both outperforming placebo (46%).
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic uncomplicated diverticular disease (SUDD) of the colon.
effective_dosage: 24 billion/day of Lactobacillus casei subsp. DG.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily consumption of a synbiotic yogurt containing Lactobacillus Casei CRL431, along with other probiotics and inulin, affects gastrointestinal function and dietary intake in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that the synbiotic yogurt did not significantly alter gastrointestinal transit time but was well tolerated and helped reduce overall energy intake, particularly in participants with shorter baseline transit times. No significant changes in GI symptoms were observed.
population_specificity: 65 healthy adults, categorized into short (≤32.7 h) and long (>32.7 h) gastrointestinal transit time groups.
effective_dosage: 200 g/day of yogurt containing Lactobacillus Casei CRL431, Bifidobacterium lactis Bb12, Lactobacillus acidophilus La5, and 4 g inulin.
study_duration: Two 15-day treatment periods, each preceded by a 6-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus casei CRL 431, when added to milk, could improve growth and iron and zinc status in Indonesian children compared to milk with regular calcium alone.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei CRL 431 modestly improved monthly weight velocity but did not significantly affect height, anemia prevalence, or iron and zinc status. The effects were less pronounced than those observed with Lactobacillus reuteri DSM 17938.
population_specificity: Healthy children from low-socioeconomic urban communities in Jakarta, Indonesia (n = 494).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of Lactobacillus Casei in alleviating symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), specifically distension and flatulence, as part of a broader meta-analysis on probiotics.
results_summary: Lactobacillus Casei improved distension scores (SMD, -0.53; 95% CI, -1.00; -0.06) and flatulence (SMD, -0.60; 95% CI, -1.07; -0.13) in IBS patients, indicating a statistically significant benefit for these symptoms.
population_specificity: IBS patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota in alleviating functional constipation in otherwise-healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in constipation severity, stool frequency, consistency, or quantity compared to placebo at the 5% significance level, though re-evaluation at a 10% level showed slight improvement in constipation severity. Stool consistency showed a small but growing effect over time.
population_specificity: Adults with functional constipation (Rome II-defined).
effective_dosage: Once daily fermented milk containing L. casei strain Shirota (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the protective mechanisms of Lactobacillus casei/paracasei-produced lactocepin in reducing inflammation in experimental IBD models.
results_summary: The study found that lactocepin selectively degrades pro-inflammatory chemokines, leading to reduced immune cell infiltration and inflammation in IBD models, suggesting broad therapeutic potential for inflammatory diseases.
population_specificity: Experimental IBD models (not specified if human or animal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a probiotic drink containing Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) on immune function in a healthy older population.
results_summary: Probiotic consumption significantly increased natural killer (NK) cell activity and decreased CD25 expression in resting T cells compared to placebo. There was also a trend toward an increased anti-inflammatory cytokine profile (IL-10 to IL-12 ratio) after LcS intake.
population_specificity: Healthy, non-immunocompromised older volunteers (n=30).
study_duration: 4 weeks per treatment (with a 4-week washout period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Lactobacillus casei Shirota supplementation on insulin sensitivity, β-cell function, inflammation, and endothelial dysfunction in subjects with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvements in insulin sensitivity, β-cell function, endothelial function, or inflammation markers, except for a reduction in soluble vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (sVCAM-1) levels. The change in insulin sensitivity index was not significantly different compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Subjects with metabolic syndrome

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding Lactobacillus casei to antibiotic treatment improved symptoms in patients with SIBO compared to prebiotics.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei significantly improved 5 out of 6 symptoms in SIBO patients, showing a trend toward greater effectiveness than prebiotics, though the difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 40 patients (14 males, 26 females) with SIBO and abdominal complaints but no gastrointestinal diseases or alarm symptoms.
effective_dosage: Lactobacillus casei administered for 7 days following 7 days of Rifaximin 400 mg/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a probiotic mixture containing Lactobacillus Casei was effective in treating constipation during pregnancy.
results_summary: The probiotic mixture significantly increased defecation frequency and reduced symptoms like anorectal obstruction, incomplete evacuation, straining, abdominal pain, and reflux episodes. No side effects were reported.
population_specificity: Pregnant women aged ≥18 years with functional constipation.
effective_dosage: 4*10⁹ CFU daily (Ecologic®Relief containing multiple strains, including Lactobacillus casei W79).

study_goal: To assess the effects and safety of Lactobacillus casei rhamnosus LCR35 in patients with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).
results_summary: LCR35 showed potential efficacy in IBS patients with diarrhea, with a clinically relevant decrease in symptom severity, but no significant difference was observed in the overall population. No clinically relevant changes were noted in quality of life or anxiety/depression scores.
population_specificity: 50 patients with IBS symptoms complying with Rome III criteria, including subtypes (constipation-predominant, diarrhea-predominant, mixed, unsubtyped).
effective_dosage: Minimum daily dose of 6 × 10^8 colony forming units.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the presence and effect of orally administered Lactobacillus casei rhamnosus (LCR35) in the vagina and its impact on Nugent scores in healthy women of child-bearing age.
results_summary: The mean Nugent score decreased in both dosage groups, with a higher proportion of women in the higher dosage group (40%) carrying LCR35 at the end of the trial. The study concluded that LCR35 at 2 × 10^8 CFU/day could normalize Nugent scores via temporary vaginal presence.
population_specificity: 20 healthy women of child-bearing age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a multispecies probiotic, including Lactobacillus Casei, in preventing necrotising enterocolitis (NEC) in preterm newborns weighing <1500 g.
results_summary: The study observed a trend toward reduced NEC frequency in the probiotic group (8% vs. 16% in controls) but no statistically significant NEC risk reduction. However, a post hoc analysis showed a significantly lower combined risk of NEC or death in the probiotic group.
population_specificity: Preterm newborns weighing <1500 g.
effective_dosage: 1 g per day of a multispecies probiotic (containing Lactobacillus Casei among others).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) could reduce respiratory symptoms and improve immune response to influenza vaccination in elderly nursing home residents.
results_summary: The study found no statistically or clinically significant effect of LcS on respiratory symptom protection or influenza vaccination immune response. Both univariate and multivariate analyses showed no benefit from the probiotic intervention.
population_specificity: Elderly nursing home residents aged ≥ 65 years in Antwerp, Belgium.
effective_dosage: 2 bottles of fermented milk daily, each containing ≥ 6.5 × 10^9 live LcS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate bacterial contamination, including Lactobacillus casei, on metallic orthodontic brackets after 30 days of use.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei was detected in lower numbers compared to other cariogenic microorganisms like Streptococcus mutans and Streptococcus sobrinus (P <0.001). The study did not focus on its efficacy or safety but noted its presence among colonizing bacteria.
population_specificity: 18 patients aged 11-29 years undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus casei, combined with Bifidobacterium breve, could effectively treat antibiotic-associated diarrhea (AAD) in hospitalized patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in treatment duration, cure rates, or relapse rates between the probiotic and placebo groups, concluding that L. casei and B. breve had no effect on AAD at the administered dosage. Adverse events like bloating, abdominal cramps, and vomiting occurred equally in both groups.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients who developed diarrhea during or within 7 days of stopping antibiotic treatment.
effective_dosage: Three times a day (specific dosage not provided).
study_duration: Average treatment duration was approximately 5 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of IL-1β and caspase-1 in coronary arteritis induced by Lactobacillus casei cell wall extract (LCWE) in a murine model of Kawasaki disease.
results_summary: The study found that LCWE-induced IL-1β maturation and secretion depended on the NLRP3 inflammasome in macrophages, and both caspase-1-deficient and IL-1 receptor-deficient mice were protected from LCWE-induced coronary lesions. IL-1 receptor antagonist prevented LCWE-mediated coronary lesions, suggesting anti-IL-1β treatment as a potential therapy for Kawasaki disease.
population_specificity: Murine (mouse) model of Kawasaki disease
study_duration: Up to 3 days after LCWE injection

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Lactobacillus casei in preventing and treating diarrheal diseases, particularly antibiotic-associated diarrhea, in pediatric and adult populations.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei was among the probiotics showing clear evidence of efficacy in preventing antibiotic-associated diarrhea, though it was less prominently effective compared to Lactobacillus GG and S. boulardii. The effect was noted to be strain-dependent and dose-dependent.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult populations, including underprivileged areas and hospitalized children.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate historical methods for measuring folate status, including the use of Lactobacillus casei assays, and compare them with newer techniques.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus casei assays have been historically used to establish folate sufficiency ranges and dietary reference intakes, but newer protein binding assays and mass spectrometry methods are now being adopted despite variations in results.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on methodological comparison rather than a specific human population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Lactobacillus casei could prevent or treat small bowel injuries caused by chronic low-dose aspirin use.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus casei significantly reduced the number of mucosal breaks and improved capsule endoscopy scores compared to the control group, indicating effectiveness in treating aspirin-associated small bowel injury.
population_specificity: 35 patients taking low-dose aspirin and omeprazole with unexplained iron deficiency anemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the contamination of metallic brackets by Lactobacillus Casei and the efficacy of 0.12% chlorhexidine gluconate mouthwashes in reducing bacterial contamination.
results_summary: Lactobacillus Casei was detected in 100% of the samples from both the control and experimental groups. While all bacterial counts decreased after rinsing with chlorhexidine, the reduction for Lactobacillus Casei was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 39 patients aged 11-33 years under treatment with fixed orthodontic appliances.
effective_dosage: 0.12% chlorhexidine gluconate mouthwash used twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of milk fermented with Lactobacillus casei Shirota on constipation in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic intake significantly improved stool consistency and reduced bloating, abdominal pain, and sensation of incomplete emptying in Parkinson's disease patients with constipation.
population_specificity: Forty Parkinson's disease patients suffering from constipation according to Rome III criteria.
effective_dosage: 65 mL fermented milk drink containing 6.5×10^9 CFU of Lactobacillus casei Shirota daily.
study_duration: 5 weeks (following a 1-week baseline period with dietetic therapy alone).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of HealOzone on Lactobacillus casei in a tooth cavity model over 4 and 8 weeks.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the amount of Lactobacillus casei between the ozone-treated and control groups, indicating that L. casei was more resistant to ozone compared to Streptococcus mutans.
population_specificity: Caries-free third molars (n=12)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) supplementation could reduce the incidence of upper respiratory-tract infections (URTIs) and influence immune markers in endurance-trained individuals during winter training.
results_summary: The study found that LcS supplementation significantly reduced the frequency of URTIs and maintained higher saliva IgA levels compared to placebo, though symptom severity and duration were unaffected.
population_specificity: Highly active men and women engaged in endurance-based physical activities.
effective_dosage: Daily (specific dosage not mentioned in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) could enhance NK cell activity in healthy men with reduced NK cell lytic function.
results_summary: The study found that 4 weeks of LcS supplementation had no significant effect on NK cell numbers, function, or other immune parameters like phagocytosis, respiratory burst, or cytokine secretion.
population_specificity: Healthy men preselected for reduced NK cell lytic activity (n = 68).
study_duration: 4 weeks of supplementation, preceded by a 2-week run-in and followed by a 2-week follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether fermented milk containing Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota (LcS) could reduce hard or lumpy stools in healthy individuals with mild constipation.
results_summary: The study found that daily consumption of LcS-fermented milk significantly reduced the proportion of hard or lumpy stools (from 73.7% to 36.8%) and improved Bristol Stool Form Scale scores compared to the control group. The effects were statistically significant (P = 0.002 for H-HLS, P < 0.001 for BS score).
population_specificity: Healthy subjects with mild constipation (Bristol Stool Form Scale score < 3.0).
effective_dosage: Not specified (fermented milk containing LcS, daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the immunogenic potential and inflammatory cytokine induction of Lactobacillus casei (DN-114 001) with other probiotic strains in human and mouse immune cells.
results_summary: Lactobacillus casei induced higher levels of the proinflammatory cytokine IFN-γ compared to Bifidobacterium breve but lower than Lactobacillus rhamnosus. The cytokine induction was TLR9-dependent, with no apparent role for TLR4, NOD2, or C-type lectin receptors.
population_specificity: Human and mouse primary immune cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether yogurt containing Lactobacillus casei, as part of a probiotic blend, improved H. pylori eradication rates or reduced adverse events when added to second-line triple therapy.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in H. pylori eradication rates or reduction in adverse events when probiotic yogurt was added to the treatment regimen. The eradication rates and adverse event rates were statistically similar between the yogurt and control groups.
population_specificity: 337 patients with persistent H. pylori infection after first-line triple therapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified for Lactobacillus casei individually; yogurt contained a blend of probiotics (Lactobacillus acidophilus, Lactobacillus casei, Bifidobacterium longum, and Streptococcus thermophilus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether short-term daily intake of milk supplemented with Lactobacillus rhamnosus LB21 affects the microbial profiles or levels of caries-associated bacteria in saliva and supragingival plaque of caries-active adolescents.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in microbial profiles or levels of caries-associated bacteria between the probiotic and placebo groups after the intervention. Lactobacillus casei was frequently identified in saliva samples but its levels were not significantly altered by the probiotic intervention.
population_specificity: 18 caries-active adolescents of both sexes.
effective_dosage: 2.5 dl of milk supplemented with Lactobacillus rhamnosus LB21 (10^7 CFU/ml) once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immunomodulatory properties of Lactobacillus casei Shirota in birch-pollen-allergic subjects, focusing on its ability to reduce IL-13 levels.
results_summary: L. casei Shirota reduced the number of CD16(+)/CD56(+) cells in peripheral blood mononuclear cells but did not show significant changes in IgE or other immune markers like IL-5 and IL-13, unlike some L. plantarum strains.
population_specificity: 62 subjects with a proven birch-pollen allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of probiotic formulations, including Lactobacillus casei, in preventing Clostridium difficile infection.
results_summary: Only one study involving Lactobacillus casei and L. bulgaricus showed efficacy in preventing C. difficile infection, while other probiotic/prebiotic formulations did not demonstrate clinical benefit.
population_specificity: Patients at risk of or being treated for C. difficile infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Lactobacillus casei and Bifidobacterium breve could prevent necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) stage ≥ 2 in very-low-birth-weight preterm infants.
results_summary: The study found that NEC stage ≥ 2 occurred only in the control group (4 cases), suggesting that the probiotic combination significantly reduced NEC incidence. The improvement was attributed to enhanced intestinal motility.
population_specificity: Very-low-birth-weight preterm infants (750–1499 g at birth).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Lactobacillus casei DG on colonic microbiota, mucosal cytokine balance, and toll-like receptor expression in patients with mild left-sided ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: Rectal administration of L. casei DG, combined with 5-ASA, modified colonic microbiota by increasing Lactobacillus spp. and reducing Enterobacteriaceae, reduced TLR-4 and IL-1β mRNA levels, and increased mucosal IL-10. Oral administration of L. casei DG with 5-ASA did not significantly affect colonic flora or TLR expression.
population_specificity: 26 patients with mild left-sided ulcerative colitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (oral and rectal administration, but exact dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perioperative synbiotic therapy (including Lactobacillus casei) reduces infectious complications in patients undergoing elective living-donor liver transplantation.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotic therapy significantly reduced postoperative infectious complications (4% in the treatment group vs. 24% in the control group), with no difference in other complications.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing elective living-donor liver transplantation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (synbiotic therapy included Bifidobacterium breve, Lactobacillus casei, and galactooligosaccharides).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticaries activity of a nanoemulsion containing cetylpyridinium chloride, using a biofilm model with Streptococcus mutans and Lactobacillus casei to simulate dental caries formation.
results_summary: The nanoemulsion significantly reduced lesion depth and mineral loss compared to both the control (no treatment) and chlorhexidine groups, demonstrating superior anticaries efficacy. Lactobacillus casei was part of the biofilm model but its direct effects were not separately analyzed.
population_specificity: Human tooth enamel blocks in an artificial mouth model.
effective_dosage: Nanoemulsion applied once daily for 30 seconds.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Lactobacillus Casei as a probiotic, focusing on its immunomodulatory effects and potential use in vaccine development.
results_summary: The study highlights that Lactobacillus Casei, as part of lactic acid bacteria, plays a significant role in improving digestion, nutrient absorption, and immune response, with potential applications in oral vaccine development.
population_specificity: General animal and human populations (not specified in detail).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a fermented milk beverage containing Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota (LcS) on defecation frequency, intestinal microbiota, and the intestinal environment in healthy individuals with soft stools.
results_summary: The study found that the probiotic significantly improved stool quality (hardened), reduced defecation frequency, and increased bifidobacteria levels in stools. Live LcS was recovered in stools, and organic acid levels increased during the intake period but returned to baseline afterward.
population_specificity: Healthy adults with soft stools.
effective_dosage: 40 billion bacterial cells per bottle, 1 bottle/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a selective medium (M-RTLV agar) to distinguish Lactobacillus casei from related species and confirm its ability to detect ingested L. casei in human feces.
results_summary: The M-RTLV agar successfully distinguished L. casei/L. paracasei from L. rhamnosus based on colony color. The study confirmed the detection of ingested L. casei strain Shirota (LcS) in fecal samples, with viable counts of approximately 6.5-6.6 log(10) CFU/g feces after daily consumption of Yakult or Yakult Light.
population_specificity: Human subjects consuming Yakult or Yakult Light.
effective_dosage: One bottle daily (containing L. casei strain Shirota).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a probiotic blend containing Lactobacillus casei in reducing the incidence and duration of antibiotic-associated diarrhea (AAD) and Clostridium difficile-associated diarrhea (CDAD) in hospitalized patients.
results_summary: The study found that the probiotic blend significantly reduced the incidence and duration of AAD and CDAD compared to placebo, with higher doses (100 billion c.f.u.) showing superior outcomes and fewer gastrointestinal symptoms than lower doses (50 billion c.f.u.).
population_specificity: Adult inpatients on antibiotics.
effective_dosage: 50 billion c.f.u. (one capsule) or 100 billion c.f.u. (two capsules) per day.
study_duration: Probiotic administration began within 36 hours of antibiotic initiation and continued for 5 days after the last antibiotic dose, with a 21-day follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of probiotic supplementation, including Lactobacillus Casei, for treating constipation in adults and children.
results_summary: In adults, Lactobacillus casei Shirota showed a favorable effect on defecation frequency and stool consistency. In children, L. casei rhamnosus Lcr35 demonstrated a beneficial effect, while L. rhamnosus GG did not.
population_specificity: Adults and children with constipation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Lactobacillus casei on lipid metabolism and intestinal microflora in patients with alcoholic liver injury.
results_summary: The study found that high-dose Lactobacillus casei significantly reduced serum TG and LDLC levels and increased beneficial gut bacteria (Lactobacillus and Bifidobacterium) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with alcoholic liver injury (n=158) and a healthy control group (n=20).
effective_dosage: Low-dose (100 ml/day) and high-dose (200 ml/day) of Lactobacillus casei strain Shirota (LcS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Lactobacillus casei Shirota (LcS) on gut microbiota composition, gut barrier integrity, intestinal inflammation, and serum bile acid profile in individuals with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: LcS supplementation led to subtle microbiota changes at the genus level (enrichment of Parabacteroides) but did not significantly influence the Bacteroidetes/Firmicutes ratio, gut barrier dysfunction (zonulin and calprotectin levels), or serum bile acid profiles in metabolic syndrome patients.
population_specificity: 28 subjects with metabolic syndrome (13 received LcS, 15 controls), compared to 16 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if high-dose Lactobacillus casei supplementation for 7 days enhances salivary antimicrobial protein responses to exertional-heat stress.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in resting salivary antimicrobial protein responses with probiotic supplementation compared to placebo. While some increases in specific salivary markers occurred after exertional-heat stress, the probiotic did not provide additional immune protection over placebo.
population_specificity: Eight endurance-trained male volunteers (age 26 ± 6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Lactobacillus reuteri in exacerbating CPT11-induced intestinal mucositis by examining its impact on gut microbiota and intestinal stem cell differentiation.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus reuteri, a GUS-expressing bacterium, worsened CPT11-induced mucositis by impairing intestinal stem cell differentiation and epithelial regeneration, while its elimination alleviated symptoms and preserved stem cell function.
population_specificity: CPT11-treated mice and clinical patients with mucositis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Lactobacillus casei subsp. Rhamnosus (LGG) supplementation affects infant gut microbiota composition and its potential role in preventing allergic diseases.
results_summary: Infants with high LGG abundance showed promotion of phylogenetically clustered probiotic species and more even microbial distribution, characteristics linked to resistance against pathogens and reduced atopy-associated taxa. The findings suggest LGG may protect against allergic disease by fostering a stable, balanced gut community.
population_specificity: 6-month-old infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the immunomodulating effects of Tyndallized (heat-killed) Lactobacillus reuteri postbiotics on canine peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) to assess their potential for managing atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: The study found that Tyndallized Lactobacillus reuteri significantly increased levels of Th1 cytokines (IL-12, IFN-γ) and IL-10 (associated with T regulatory cells), while Th2 cytokine (IL-4) levels remained stable, suggesting an anti-allergic immune response.
population_specificity: Healthy dogs
study_duration: PBMCs were incubated for up to 72 hours

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the in vitro inhibitory effects of Lactobacillus reuteri strain I300 against H. pylori, focusing on adhesion, invasion, and inflammation modulation.
results_summary: L. reuteri I300 and its formulations significantly reduced H. pylori adhesion and invasion of AGS cells, decreased proinflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-8), increased anti-inflammatory cytokine (IL-10), and upregulated E-cadherin expression to promote epithelial cell integrity.
population_specificity: In vitro study using AGS cells (human gastric adenocarcinoma cell line) and H. pylori.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if short-term high-dose probiotic supplementation with Lactobacillus casei could reduce exertional-heat stress-induced endotoxinaemia and cytokinaemia.
results_summary: The study found that L.casei supplementation did not significantly attenuate endotoxinaemia or cytokinaemia compared to placebo, with only minor trends in higher endotoxin and TNF-α levels post-exercise.
population_specificity: Eight endurance-trained male volunteers (age 26 ± 6 years, VO2max 59 ± 5 ml·kg-1·min-1).
effective_dosage: Volume equivalent to 10^11 colony forming units per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus reuteri NCHBL-005 enhances fibroblast-mediated wound healing through TLR2 stimulation and MAPK pathway activation.
results_summary: L. reuteri NCHBL-005 significantly accelerated wound closure in fibroblasts, activated the MAPK pathway, and promoted fibroblast proliferation and differentiation, with TLR2 being critical for this mechanism. In vivo studies confirmed enhanced wound healing and fibroblast activation.
population_specificity: L929 fibroblast cells, mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs), and wound models in mice (including TLR2-/- mice).

study_goal: To assess the efficacy of Lactobacillus reuteri DSM 17938 as an adjunct to oral rehydration therapy in treating acute gastroenteritis in children.
results_summary: L. reuteri reduced the duration of diarrhea and frequency of watery stools compared to placebo, with significant differences observed by day 5 of treatment. The intervention was deemed safe and effective in emergency management.
population_specificity: Children aged 1 to 60 months with acute gastroenteritis and mild to moderate dehydration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and microbiological efficacy of locally administered biodegradable fibers containing Lactobacillus reuteri as an adjunct to scaling and root planing (SRP) in managing chronic periodontitis.
results_summary: The test group showed significant improvements in clinical parameters (45.66% reduction in plaque index, 57.83% reduction in bleeding index, and 43.06% improvements in probing pocket depth and clinical attachment level) and a 63.00% reduction in microbial load compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 30 patients aged 30-60 years diagnosed with chronic periodontitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of Lactobacillus reuteri in oral and systemic health and explore its potential applications in preventing and treating oral diseases.
results_summary: Lactobacillus reuteri shows promise in treating biofilm-dependent oral diseases and may benefit overall health, but its mechanisms and efficacy require further research.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human microbiota context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Lactobacillus reuteri on growth performance, intestinal immunity, and intestinal barrier integrity in weaned piglets.
results_summary: L. reuteri did not significantly affect growth performance but improved intestinal health by reducing liver enzyme levels, enhancing immunoglobulin concentrations, improving gut barrier function, and modulating inflammatory cytokine expression.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets of similar age and weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus reuteri ZJ617 supplementation could ameliorate metabolic syndrome symptoms in mice and explore its mechanism of action.
results_summary: L. reuteri ZJ617 improved metabolic syndrome symptoms in high-fat diet-induced mice by modulating host metabolism and microbiome interactions, leading to increased spermidine production. Spermidine treatment replicated these benefits, while its inhibition negated them.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced metabolic syndrome mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary supplementation with Lactobacillus reuteri postbiotics on growth performance, intestinal flora structure, and plasma metabolome in weaned piglets.
results_summary: The study found that Lactobacillus reuteri postbiotics reduced piglet mortality by 6.37%, improved antioxidant function (increased superoxide dismutase, decreased malondialdehyde), and modulated intestinal flora (increased Firmicutes, decreased Bacteroides). It also elevated fecal propionic and butyric acid levels and serum coenzyme Q10.
population_specificity: Weaned male piglets with uniform weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus reuteri (LR) could alleviate intestinal inflammation caused by immunotherapy without compromising the antitumor efficacy of the engineered strain REP.
results_summary: LR modulated inflammatory markers (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-10) via the JNK pathway, reducing intestinal inflammation while maintaining REP's antitumor effects. The combination showed no detectable systemic toxicity beyond mild intestinal damage.
population_specificity: Breast cancer model (likely murine, based on context).
effective_dosage: Not specified for LR alone (REP dosage was 10^8 CFU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether L. reuteri could alleviate hyperoxia-induced lung injuries in mice and whether its effects were mediated via the IL-22/STAT3 pathway.
results_summary: L. reuteri and its metabolite 3-IAld reduced lung injury, decreased proinflammatory cytokines, and increased protective proteins (SPC, AQP5, VEGFR2). The protective effects were linked to IL-22 production and STAT3 activation.
population_specificity: Preterm infant model (hyperoxia-induced lung injury in mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanisms by which Lactobacillus reuteri improves intestinal barrier function and glucose homeostasis, particularly through its metabolite eicosatrienoic acid (ETA).
results_summary: The study found that L. reuteri gavage increased ETA levels, which promoted GLP-1 secretion via CD36-activated signaling, enhancing intestinal barrier integrity and improving glucose homeostasis in high-fat diet (HFD) and db/db mice. These effects were mediated through the PI3K/AKT/HIF-1α pathway, reducing inflammation and serum LPS levels.
population_specificity: HFD-fed mice and db/db mice (a model for type 2 diabetes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of L. reuteri LY2-2 in alleviating colitis in mice and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: L. reuteri LY2-2 significantly reduced colitis severity by lowering pro-inflammatory cytokines, inhibiting TLR4-NF-κB signaling, restoring immune balance, and improving gut barrier function. It also modulated macrophage polarization and improved gut microbiota composition, outperforming the 5-ASA drug control.
population_specificity: Mice with DSS-induced colitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Lactobacillus reuteri TISTR 2736 on glucose homeostasis, carbohydrate metabolism, and related mechanisms in type 2 diabetic rats.
results_summary: L. reuteri TISTR 2736 improved fasting blood glucose, glucose intolerance, insulin sensitivity, hepatic histopathology, and reduced oxidative stress and inflammation in diabetic rats by modulating the IRS1/PI3K/AKT pathway.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic rats induced by a high-fat diet and streptozotocin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Lactobacillus reuteri and LGG on social behavior, gut health, and oxidative stress in a rat model of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) induced by prenatal LPS exposure.
results_summary: Lactobacillus reuteri improved social deficits, reduced anxiety, enhanced colonic barrier integrity, modified short-chain fatty acid profiles, and mitigated oxidative stress and inflammation in LPS-exposed rats and Caco-2 cells.
population_specificity: Offspring of LPS-exposed pregnant rats (ASD model) and H2O2-induced oxidative stress in Caco-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cancer therapeutic efficacy of extracellular vesicles derived from Lactobacillus reuteri (REVs) when administered orally, both independently and in combination with other therapies.
results_summary: REVs demonstrated stability in the gastrointestinal tract and significant anti-tumor effects by modulating apoptotic signaling pathways in A549 cells and murine models. Combining REVs with drugs enhanced tumor ablation and induced immunogenic cell death, with complete tumor elimination observed in a mouse model after 32 days of oral REV administration combined with photothermal therapy.
population_specificity: A549 cells and murine models (mice)
interactions: Enhanced tumor ablation when combined with drugs and photothermal therapy
